reviewText:
I grew up playing the Nintendo version of Bionic Commando (there was an arcade version too) and loved the game enough to still play it to completion every year. It was the first game that had a swear and a gruesome scene of someone's head blowing up. For those that haven't played or heard of Bionic Commando, its a 2D gunning platformer with a world map and different, unique and vibrant levels with a wide variety of enemies. If you think you've done every 2D platformer before, have you tried a platformer with no jump button? This game really hangs its hat on the fact that you use a bionic arm for platform traversal. The arm is pretty versatile, the normal arm button launches it diagonally, when you use a direction and the arm it will blast out forward, and ducking while using the arm will send it forward, but lower. You can use the arm upward too. With the arm you can swing and climb. You can release the arm's grasp to drop and release the swing. In this version of the game you can grapple barrels, pick them up and throw them. Its a nice touch. You can also use your arm to counter bullets. Its a nice feature.

With the overhead map you and your helicopter pilot will fly around to different areas / levels. There are two types of areas. Combat zones and neutral zones where you'll talk with people, obtain items that will help you and club a prisoner with your bionic arm. The combat zones have been modernized while still giving them a vibrant, colorful feel that makes it feel like a game in a good way. The excellent old chip tunes have been modernized and they all sound good, but personally, I prefer the older tunes.

The combat areas have a two or three sections, usually broken up with a communication room that will further the story for you and open doors to the next segment of the area. So an outside area will go indoors, a towering spire will reveal the upper half of the spire when you use the communication room. You can also wire tap in the communication room and new to this version of Bionic Commando is a simple mini game that has you hurling a yellow ball in a three dimensional box. If the ball exits the box, then you fail, but there's no consequence for failing like the Nintendo classic where enemies would flood the room. The goal is to rotate the box and hurtle the ball to yellow blocks that will prevent the ball from going out of bounds. Its pretty easy and it breaks up the game. Its just extra icing on the cake. The game also has communication chips like the old game, so in certain areas you'll need to have the blue chip to communicate. The Nintendo version of the game had you pick a weapon, a communication chip and an item when entering each level. Thankfully this version lets you use all of your chips, which will spare you some time.

As for the weapons, to be honest, its a little underwhelming. You have your standard 2 bullets on screen revolver, a weak laser, a short range shotgun, a rocket launcher and a bouncing laser that shoots at an angle. The angled laser can shoot enemies hiding behind cover or above you, but since the game gives you so many other ways to kill covered enemies it seems useless.. The original Nintendo game had a 3 way gun that felt useful and the original rocket launcher would plow through enemies. Now there seems to be an emphasis on realism where the explosion of the rocket launcher will damage if not kill you. The rockets also wave, giving it a chance to miss. The shotgun does the same damage as two bullets from your revolver. The weapons just feel useless when compared to the simple starting revolver. You'll be able to change your weapons on the fly with the shoulder buttons, which again is a welcome tweak to gameplay from the Nintendo version forcing you to be stuck with one weapon the entire level. The most useful weapon not in the Nintendo version is a simple grenade. So you use 3 buttons, arm, gun and grenade throw. Its a good way to kill enemies behind cover.

On the map, your helicopter moves along lines level to level, giving you choice of where to go. The only catch is that convoys patrol these lines and if you run into one, you'll fight in a top down stage. Its nice combat diversity that doesn't last long. You can use your arm to whip away bullets, but each of these areas is over quickly. You can find easy lives this way.

One of the biggest changes from the Nintendo to the Rearmed version is 2 player co-op through the levels and also multi-player death match mode. They feel like good add ons, but for those that like the single player, the biggest change are the bosses. The original Nintendo bosses were more like enemy rooms with a core at the center. Now the bosses are giant machines for the most part. These machines take a good chunk of time to destroy, have different patterns and phases of the boss fight. Its a really nice change to the original. Plus, the bosses have some character and brief dialog before each fight. It adds a lot of charm to the game.

As for challenge, the game is easier than the Nintendo version. You can take more damage, you have more attacks and can use multiple items at once. There is no real consequence to the game like there was on Nintendo. There are unlimited continues, using all of your lives merely sends you to the map. The game feels easier and you can take more bullets before you die.

In later areas when using the arm on horizontally moving platforms, the arm is suddenly very flawed. It will let go quickly if the platform you are on is moving. Sometimes, climbing onto a moving platform will nudge you off the back of it. You can even run against the movement where suddenly you're running in place when the platform is moving to the left and you are running to the right. Or trying to drop off platforms will sometimes bump you back onto them. Toward the end of the game it turns into a fight against the game's mechanic on top of what can already be a forgiving arm hit detection that doesn't always grab onto things. A lot of the time the arm will grab onto something as its retracting. The Nintendo version had that flaw too, but it wasn't nearly as abundant as in Rearmed.

For children of the 80s this was a difficult game on Nintendo, but now it might run you 4 hours to complete. There are a few difficulties to chose from too. I can say that $2.50 is a good price for the game, but I have difficulty justifying $10 for a game this old that is really just a fresh coat of paint with some memorable bosses. The levels are quick and don't offer much challenge to veterans who have already completed the game 20+ years ago. There are a few new levels including the final level that feels excessively long. There are plenty of challenge rooms inside non combat zones where you're forced to get from point A to point B, but that's hardly an attraction. The game has in game medals, but no Steam achievements. After everything being said, I prefer the original and I think that the sequel to this remake is a better game, mostly because I felt like I hadn't already played it.

Bionic Commando is an amazing recreation of the classic NES game from Capcom. The original game is near and dear to my heart, so I had pretty lofty expectations for the remastered and modernized version.

Needless to say, I was not disappointed.

Bionic Commando does just about everything you could hope for in terms of taking the things that made a golden age classic into the new generation. The controls are fluid and tight, the graphics are amazing, and the soundtrack...oh wow.

This isn't a game you will breeze through. Bionic Commando forces the player to practice, honing their skills with each new play session. The game is challenging, but not overly difficult in a frustrating way.

Whether you have played the NES classic, or are looking to experience the game for the first time, I can't recommend Bionic Commando enough.

Excellent remaster


Bionic Commando: Rearmed is a remaster, developed by Capcom, of the orginal 'Bionic Commando' released on the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES).


The Good- Audio = Remix of old soundtrack from orignal game. Sounds great whilst maintaining its roots.
- Graphics
- Story
- Atmosphere
- Unique gameplay = Unlike other platformer, you can't jump and have to rely on your 'Claw' get past obstacles or climb platforms. The claw also deflects bullets and has other uses as well.
- 12 level campaign
- 56 challenge maps = Mainly testing your skills with the 'Bionic Arm'. People looking for a REAL challenge will enjoy these.
- Co-op = Done locally, where you tackle the campaign with a friend.
- Multiplayer = Done locally where up to four players face off in a stage.
- Diverse difficulty levels = There are 3, with the fourth unlocked after completing campaign. Levels determine the number of enemies and traps encountered.
- Variety of weapons = Besides your standard rifle you can get: Machine gun, rocket launcher, shotgun, link gun and grenades.
- Plenty of secrets = Secret areas are located in each level which contain a unique weapon upgrade.
- Helpful Tutorial = Must play for beginners as it teaches you the essentials to completing the game.


The Bad- Controls = They are not too bad (I played with M+keyboard), but this game was definitely made to be played with controller.
- No online co-op or multiplayer
- May need walkthrough = Some stages and boss fights might get a bit tricky.


Final VerdictVeteran of the orignal, will love this remaster as well as those looking for a unique and challenging action-platformer.

reviewText:
I came here with the purpose of finding a game I didn't like and seeing if it was worth a negative review.
Glad I came back to this one.  As it turns out, its a rough diamond.

Its a jarring game to play initially.  We are so used to knowing what a shooter is and what a platformer is.  When a game like Bionic Commando denies us a jump button then it becomes very stressful.  My advice is do the tutorials and attempt the challenge rooms within the friendly zones first.

They will teach you the mechanics and you will quickly be able to move fluidly the way you want to and be a true bionic commando, instead of a slow clunky frustrated commando wondering what you are doing.

The swing mechanics of the bionic arm are very fun once you take a few minutes to get used to them, and you will be taking on platforms and bad guys with ease quickly.  You won't even mind not having a jump button after you've figured it all out.

Level progression is a bit different too.  Area 0 is a friendly zone that must be entered to find the tutorial, and Area 1 must be entered to find the challenge rooms that put into practice more of the advanced skills.

You won't initially know where to go, but by exploring the areas you can access you will eventually build up a handy arsenal of equipment and knowledge of the game.   I highly recommend exploring all the friendly zone to start with and entering the rooms to collect useful equipment as well as getting used to moving around outside of combat.  After you've comfortably explored the friendly areas and rooms, tackle the nearby accessable low numbered areas and dominate those enemies in combat.

As an example of a time where you will be initially confused, you need to explore a friendly zone to get the flares you need to more easily explore Area 4.  The level can still possibly be completed, but you will get frustrated wondering why an early level has you zipping about blind trying to find a random platform or bit of wall you need to succeed.  Turns out exploration of a friendly zone was the answer and only one I discovered by accident after getting frustrated and quitting out to try another stage.

Bosses are in every enemy stage, and there is a great mechanic where you can hack enemy consoles for a chance of learning the boss weakness.  I found the early bosses to be easy enough that I didn't get frustrated and wanted to keep playing.  Beating bosses earns you more gear as well as more levels to play with so its a rewarding experience.

There are also enemy trucks zipping about the world map also give you a chance to play a different kind of shooting game and experiment with weapons.  Its a bit repetitive, but a fun distraction between the main game.

In conclusion, Bionic Commando Rearmed is definitely a game that tries something different and succeeds.  If you can cope with it being different, put in that half an hour to learn how to play the game.  There is a real treat lying ahead for you.

EDIT: I'll admit later levels and challenges do become frustrating so just enjoy the fun bits.

Simply put, Bionic Commando: Rearmed is the greatest remake in the history of gaming. Not only does the game have incredibly pleasing visuals and music, but the tight gameplay from the original NES game is still fully intact, with some innovations as well.

If you haven't played this game or the original, basically you're a guy with a grapple arm and you can't jump. You get around by swinging from stuff, and which way your grapple goes all depends on which direction you hold down. The controls are so damn precise that after a while you'll instinctively be pulling off all kinds of sweet grapples and be swinging around like spiderman. The level design takes heavy inspiration from the original but some of the levels have been modified, as well as many of the boss fights which can prove to be challenging if you lose your cool. On top of that, there's TONS of challenge levels that will keep you playing long after you've beaten the game, allowing you to hone your grapple skills even further.

Rearmed is worth your money. Hands down. Buy it.
And yes, you still get to blow up Hitler's face with a rocket, and see it in all of it's goryness.

My only real complaints have been that it's a bit short -- I would love to see Rearmed 2's levels released as a DLC pack, but they're currently a console exclusive -- and even with the relearning curve, I breezed through it, my first time, in under two  hours. I doubt it's going to see much new love, as it's an older title now, but nonetheless, that's really the only thing I found myself wanting for, in it. In fairness, though, I really did love the 1988 NES version, and I wanted this to be a very faithful, but slightly tweaked and improved, version of it. It is -- and if that appeals to you as it appealed to me, you're going to love Rearmed. If you're hoping for a dramatic update, it is, but if you're hoping for a dramatic departure, look elsewhere. This was, in my admittedly biased opinion, an attempt to revive the best damned platformer of the NES, and Grin seems to have treated its source material with all the reverence I would have wanted them to apply to such a legendary game.

This isn't for everyone: it's a very faithful recreation of a singularly unique NES game. But it is very much what it sets out to be, and that's a thing of real beauty in this day and age of weaksauce nostalgic property reboots. The only game like it that I've encountered was the remastered edition of Ducktales, a similarly brilliant and reverent resurrection of a past classic.

reviewText:
A remake of the classic NES title that seems to stay very true to its core gameplay mechanics whilst also adding other content.

Plays fine on a keyboard but a controller would probably be more recommended whatwith it being a platformer. The controller input isn't rebindable and there are preset control types the game allows you to use but the controls themselves should be relatively simple enough to play through with.

Difficulties range from Easy, Medium, and Hard. From what I see Hard mode on this game overall makes it a bit harder than the NES Bionic Commando with its high number, damage resisting, beefed up enemy count and Spencer being able to sustain fewer damage.

As it goes like with the NES one there are two kinds of gameplay, its core platforming sections which is basically 90% of the game and the occassional top-down shooter sections. The top-down shooter sections are as occassional as before. When trying to select an stage you do so from a somewhat visually appalling-in-comparison mapscreen where you're a helicopter hovering over a numbered Area to descend to. The top-down shooter sections will only come up likely by chance because you happen to be trying to select an area to descend to from the overhead map and and an enemy truck on the map happens to come your way. It's still as basic as ever; top-down perspective, shoot anything that shoots back with its extremely simplistic controls (with the new addition of the movement via the analog stick) and style like with any other game of its kind. The usual end-goal exit has been replaced with a non-retaliating obstruction that you have to destroy. You can breeze right through these sections with little to no trouble especially if you've acquired a strong enough weapon or two. Used to be that the only good reason to do these top-down shooter parts is to collect obtainable Continues from specific enemies. This time around they're unlimited so there's no real good reason to actually make a forward attempt to go do these anymore although lives are still a thing but I'm not entirely sure if you can farm those properly.
You get 2 (or 3, I forget) lives by default. As tradition would go doing a proper job at staying alive and completing a level won't result in much inconveniences with starting a level over at a point especially if all lives have been wasted.

Most of the mechanics & features in the NES version have made it here and work pretty much the same way, like the bionic arm still being able to block bullets if the action's performed right and only being able to respawn from the beginning of the stage & most doorways, specifically & especially the ones that enable access to boss doors.
Its core mechanic is the replacement of a jump button/option to a bionic arm that allows you to grapple in 5 directions (←, ↖, ↑, ↗ →) onto platforms for either climbing or swinging likely consistently in succession. Learning bionic arm platforming may take a bit of time to learn fully and get used to but I thought it was pretty worth it when put to proper use. There are even some tutorial and challenge levels to help get a better handle with it.
At least on Medium difficulty and later, there are no longer any enemies that die in one hit with weaker weapons. You also have a health bar now as opposed to the squares that indicate how many hits you can take from anything. This also means that there are no longer any collectible bullets" to pick up from killed enemies as the bullets have been replaced by obtainable Score Tokens and random health refills.
A few items and weapons from the NES one have been replaced by many newer ones (weapons mostly) that are actually all very useful in the right situation as I never actually found myself picking favorites. Every item & weapon you acquire are now all automatically equipped with the ability to switch weapons in-game. You can find upgrades for each weapon however you'd have to put in effort into locating them as they're pretty much all hidden in secret areas.

Practically all of the notable parts of every stage in this game are kept the way they are with some changes made for better or worse like complete scenery/atmosphere overhauls and other additions to prolong the stages a bit maybe. A few bosses have been replaced with more new ones to add variety in these fights one way or another they've been redesigned. In the later half of the game you'll have to fight most of them again in their upgraded forms. Plus
date: you actually have to fight them now because the choice to skip a fight altogether has been removed. The final boss fight too has been completely redone and now has his own incredibly long specific stage with the final escape still mostly being the way it is as it was.\n\nIt's just a personal issue but I didn't find the visuals & graphics & whatever the like to be all too appropriate with the gameplay but all-in-all I enjoyed it and thought that it pretty much played almost exactly and then some like the NES title."

A good game with some jarringly stressful levels at the end, namely the upper swinging section in 11 where you have to be very precise and a slight mispress of the claw arm button, which your press only has to be off by a milisecond, means having to re-navigate the bottom section to get back up for another most likely unsuccessful try. Then you have the final albatros level. It just ♥♥♥♥ing sucks. The first part, your claw arm doesn't work half the time on some of the platforms in one section, an obvious game glitch, and the rest is just a pure stress test. If your doctor ever wants you to take a stress test, tell him no thanks, you have already played Bionic Commando Rearmed. The last albatros level is the worst level I have ever seen in a video game. It was so incredibly stressful and so bull-shi--y that I just got tired of it and gave up and uninstalled the game because I just stopped caring, never to be ♥♥♥♥ed with again. You get through three door tests that are stupid enough in their own right, then the next section has changing platforms and collapsing hook grapple points. I was laughing at how stupidly stressful it was and just quit and am done with this game. Such a shame, all that work for such a truly God awful last level.

Everything is good, but it will take some getting used to for most people because it is a platformer without a jump button. The idea is that your bionic arm is so heavy that you can't jump but you can sure as hell use it to swing around the levels awkwardly and that is the whole thing that made Bionic Commando unique in the first place, since the original. Everything works fine and it is a challenging game so some things are going to be immensely stressful in the levels but it is do-able with practice. The challenge levels in particular are probably the hardest, most stressful things I have ever done in my life, Unfortunately a lot of the picky awful programming that forces you to have perfect timing in the challenge levels trickles over into the story missions. On the 10th challenge I had no idea how to swing up to do it until I checked a youtube video. Even after watching how it was done I still had no idea how to do it until I read some detailed comments under the video and even then I still pretty much did it by luck. I gave up after the second set of them. The third set of challenges just got too stressful. I have never in my life seen anything require you to be so incredibly precise. If you don't swing right even for a milisecond you fail. If you dont hit the button within the right milisecond you fail. There is quite literally zero margin of error in the challenges, but thankfully they are not required so I am just enjoying the story levels. The graphics are awesome, the music is superb and is the best part of the game, the weapons and enemies solid, the animations realistic, and the gameplay is smooth. The only real way the game could be improved is if the dumb overly picky swing section in 11 was fixed and the last level wasn't so nightmarishly bad.

The combat is ♥♥♥♥ing stressful as well because there is no recovery time so one hit and you are sometimes bouncing around like a pinball into other hits and you can either be killed in no time or be easily bounced off a platform and fall a long, long way down and have to reclimb the level which absolutely sucks. If only your guy wasn't such a stiff heavy snail with incredibly picky claw arm swing controls then it would be less frustrating.

6/10, nothing but pure stress at the end. Get the 2009 Bionic Commando instead. The swinging in it is not done very well (gee what a surprise!) but it is not too bad and the game is still enjoyable but very short. The claw arm idea instead of a jump button is a very neat idea but it really should stay in these games and not be adopted by any others. Catch it (the 2009 3D version) only on sale though for $5 or less because it is a very short game.

reviewText:
If you remember Bionic Commando from the NES, this is simply the same thing reskinned.  This game is really just a nostalgia bomb.  If you never played the original, you may find the grapple-swing platforming mechanics odd and not super fun.

Boss battles seem to be slightly different and there's a hacking mini game at the communication stations that's new, but apart from that it tries to be a faithful reproduction of the original.  Best part?  The remixed music from the old game.  SOLID soundtrack here.  They really did make this an honest redo of the NES version, even modeling the drawings of the characters between missions and in communication sessions after the originals.  They even clip the text the same.

Nostalgia is heavy for me here, but without that historical perspective, it's a hard game to recommend.  I'll give two prices on this.  $2 if you never played Bionic Commando and $5 if you did.  It is fun, but it's not going to be the best game you play this year… probably not even this month.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game but it is killed by the same crappy control scheme that the original NES version was infamous for. Back in those NES glory days, we kids never questioned why a bionic commando would be unable to jump or climb over an obstacle. Now, though, it’s stupid and frustrating.

Many positive reviews celebrate this as being a “hard” game, but all of its difficulty stems from the crappy controls. It shouldn’t be rewarded for bad design. I could get over not being able to jump or climb if the grappling mechanics were smooth and responsive, but they aren’t. They’re clunky & counter intuitive. And this in a game full of instant death areas that oh by the way gives you a certain number of lives to get through each level.

I stopped this after about an hour, once I reached a level with a secret area I could not get into after dying & starting all the way over five times. I knew exactly what I had to do and it wasn’t very complicated, but the controls are so unresponsive it became impossibly hard. Then I thought about how, if I did manage to make it into the secret area, I would have to navigate back out the way I came and survive through the rest of the level and the boss fight. If I ran out of lives before that, I’d have to do the entire level all over again. Who thinks that’s fun?

This game could have been great if they had retooled the grappling system and the level designs. Instead they essentially lifted everything straight from the NES original aside from the graphics. If they weren’t going to update the controls, they should have at least given infinite lives & checkpoints inside levels since the gameplay boils down to tons of trial, error & luck. I bought this during a Steam sale and I regret the purchase. My advice is to get an emulated version of the original NES version. It will give you almost the same experience.

For some reason your guy can only shoot straight forward, and the idea of having his gun point up or down is soo crazy and would make things much easier, but that would just make too much sense. So then there's the arm. For having your game based on this, the swinging and arm mechanics controls are TERRIBLE. You have to press down while falling to shoot sideways. Half the time you will press up and it will shoot sideways. For having to direct it the controls are just super janky. Also, when you fall, for some reason you break the rules of physics and momentum doesn't carry you forward, you drop straight down, unlike any platformer ever. Also the swing mechanics are super terrible, sometimes you just pull up the line, others you swing and let go, and others you hold on. It is unpredictable and not easy to do at all, leading to countless deaths. Most of the time you die you realize its not your fault, its the poor game mechanics or arm controls or stupid restrictions placed on you. Then there are bosses, who they repeat after you beat them.....classic lazy design move. Yes, yes, and yes.
Bionic Commando was a game for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) and it did something other platformers of the era didnt: It managed to bring in a game changing mechanic, and not ♥♥♥♥ it up. That would be the grappling hook. Instead of jumping, you would swing from platforms over rows of spikes while shooting at enemies. This game mechanic added a whole new layer of depth to the game, and to be honest, Bionic Commando wouldnt be what it is today if it werent for the grappling hook mechanic.
So when the game was getting a remake, everyone got excited. That hype was fullfilled. But let us get into the review.

-WHAT THEY DID RIGHT-

-The graphics are awesome. They have a nice cartoony feel, enemies, players, and backgrounds all look great.
-The dialogue is so yes. Cutscenes are creative and funny, it really gets you in the mood for the fight.
-The music is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. Absolutely brilliant remixed Bionic Commando tracks.
-The bosses are excellent. They really changed up the bosses from the NES version, To be honest, the bosses for Bionic Commando NES play pretty much the same, So in Rearmed they were completely remade, from the area they take place in to the fight itself.
-Levels are fun and well designed. Nearly every level in Rearmed was a blast to play, from the action, to the puzzle elements involving the grappling hook.
-RPG Elements work really well. You must beat certain levels in order to get certain items or weapons, which you need to get past the next level. You can also go to peaceful areas in-which you can find more items.
-Coop and deathmatch. The coop mode is very fun, and deathmatch is AWESOME.

-WHAT THEY DID WRONG-

-While bosses are awesome, They are also hard. Argueably too hard. There is nothing more annoying than dieing to an unexpected attack and then having to restart the whole stage.
-Some bosses are just rehashs. They have no excuse for this. They remade the bosses, so why not remake the rehashs into their own thing?
-Levels can be too long. Most notably the Albatross. That stage is the hardest simply because when you die, you have to go through the loooonngg level again.
-No online multiplayer.
-When you tab out the game gets jittery until you restart. Why??

Despite those issues, Bionic Commando Rearmed is a masterpiece. The gameplay is fun, The music is awesome, the bosses and unique, And the story is great.

Bionic Commando Rearmed gets a 9/10

This game is absolutely brilliant. If you never played Bionic Commando on the NES, you don't need to do so to enjoy this game as it is better in pretty much every way possible. There are however plenty of eastereggs and funny references that fans of the original game will appreciate.

The difficulty level has been stepped up with multiple difficulty settings avalible, and the AI is very impressive for a 2D platformer. All the boss battles have also been completely changed for the better, and if you choose to play in coop their behavior adjust so that team work is required to destroy them. In the original game weapons had very little importance, but this time around every weapon is uniqe and has its own useful applications, which is nice given that the enemy variety has been improved as well. If you were unaware, the gimmick in this game is that you cannot jump and have to rely on using a grapple hook arm to get around. The arm functions pretty much the same way it did in the original game, but with some added features such as the ability to pick up and throw barrels as well as some enemies.

The ONE issue I have with this game is that if you play on a keyboard you won't be able to control your RC rockets separately from your walking, which makes the final encounter notoriously more difficult.
